2.  Control of Filamentous Bacteria			

The gaseous chlorine is drawn from 150 lb chlorine cylinders and mixed with a water stream by a chlorinator to form a concentrated solution of hypochlorous acid and dissolved chlorine gas.  This solution is fed into the return activated sludge line immediately after the chlorine and water are mixed.

The chlorine solution reacts with return sludge attacking the filamentous bacteria before being consumed.  The purpose for the chemical addition is only for control of the filamentous bacteria.

The amount of chlorine added is controlled by a Wallace and Tiernan model V-100 chlorinator.  Actual quantities of chlorine fed are determined by Process Control Analysis and manually adjusted on the chlorinator.



SULFUR DIOXIDE PROCESS CHEMISTRY INFORMATION

As mentioned in the above description sulfur dioxide is used for neutralizing any residual chlorine before plant effluent is discharged to the receiving waters.  Analyzer number two analyses the effluent for residual chlorine levels and adds sulfur dioxide accordingly.  Gaseous sulfur dioxide is drawn from 2000 pound capacity sulfur dioxide cylinders and mixed with water by the sulfonator to form a weak sol

ution of sulfurous acid.  This solution is mixed with the chlorinated treatment plant effluent.  The chemical reaction of dechlorination results in the conversion of all active positive chlorine ions to the nonactive negative chloride ions.

V.	PROCESS HAZARD ANALYSIS

The City of Westminster will use the ?What-If? methodology to determine and evaluate the hazards associated with the chlorination and dechlorination processes at the facility.  The following is the ?What-If?, analysis and Hazard Analysis Summary Sheets for the Westminster Plant.

The ?What-If? and Hazard Analysis Summary Sheets will be updated every five (5) years by an evaluation team meeting the requirements below.  All analyses and updates will be retained until such time that the process is eliminated.

The Process Hazard Analysis team will be comprised of individuals with expertise in engineering and process operations.  The team will include one employee who has experience and knowledge in the process being evaluated.  At least one member of the team will be knowledgeable in the ?What-If? analysis methodology being used at the facility.  If the facility processes are changed before the first schedule analysis date, the analysis will be scheduled five (5) years from the date the changes became effective.

Please refer to the City of Westminster Audit and Training Compliance Schedule at the end of this program.

This facility is scheduled for reevaluation in the first quarter of 2004.

POLICY STATEMENT

The Occupational Safety and Health Administration has established standards pertaining to process safety management of highly hazardous chemicals (29CFR1910.119-Process Safety Standard).  The purpose of this standard is to establish specific requirements for those companies which use, manufacture or store specified highly hazardous chemicals in order to prevent or minimize the effects of catastrophic release of toxic, reactive, flammable or explosive chemicals.

It is the intent of the City of Westminster to protect its employees as well as the community its serves from the dangers associated with these chemicals and to comply with all applicable federal and state standards.  In order to achieve this goal, the policies and procedures within this program have been established.

APPLICATION

The following procedures pertain to the chemicals chlorine and sulfur dioxide at or above the specified threshold quantity listed in Appendix A of 29CFR1910.119.  The threshold quantity for chlorine, CAS number 7782-50-5, is 1, 500 lbs.  Generally, chlorine is used in wastewater treatment operations to disinfect the final effluent.  Sulfur dioxide is used to remove chlorine before the effluent enters the receiving waters.  The threshold quantity for sulfur dioxide, CAS. Number 746-09-5 is 1,500 lbs.

We have included the American Water Works Association Standard for liquid chlorine ANSI/AWWA B301-92 and for sulfur dioxide ANSI/AWWA B512-91 as part of our program.  The procedures are not applicable to hydrocarbon fuels used solely for workplace consumption as a fuel.

The City of Westminster has identified the following facility as "covered" under the auspices of the Process Safety Management Standard.

III.	EMPLOYEE INVOLVEMENT & TRAINING

   A.	Employee Involvement

1.The City of Westminster Wastewater Treatment Plant  Process Safety

Management Program has been developed by key personnel from the plant                   and management. All employees of the Cities Waste Water Treatment Plant                  are trained in the covered    processes.

2.Key personnel were selected  based on their process knowledge.


   B.	Employee Training

Using the Hazard Communication Standard as a guideline the City of Westminster Wastewater Treatment Plant has developed a training program. The program is designed to ensure that all employees of the treatment plant are trained in the hazards associated with the use of chlorine and sulfur dioxide as covered under the Process Safety Management Program. Designated to develop the training program and review the methodology is the city engineer, the utilities manager and the management staff of the wastewater treatment plant. Designated to conduct the training will be the management staff of the City of Westminster Wastewater Treatment Plant. Those individuals will include the plant superintendent, the assistant superintendent, the senior operator and the shift supervisors. 

Prior to handling chlorine and sulfur dioxide all new employees are trained in the  hazards associated with the chemicals. Following training the new or transferred employee then works closely with another skilled employee until such time that the  management staff determines that the new or transferred employee is sufficiently  skilled. The methodology used to train all employees in the potential hazards associated with chlorine and sulfur dioxide is:

    1. A pretest is given to evaluate employees knowledge of the subject and to serve as         a study guide during the remainder of the training. 

    2. Classroom instruction including related videos, handouts and discussion is used to         train the employees of the hazards associated with chlorine and sulfur dioxide.

    3. A post test is given to evaluate the effectiveness of the training with a

minimum              score of  80% required to complete training. If the score achieved is less than 80%        the employee is retrained the those areas in which the employee was deficient and retested until a score of 80% is achieved.       

    4. To reinforce the classroom training a hands-on onstration is given by a member of the management staff. 
                                                                         III-1


Refresher Training

Any modifications to the existing processes will require additional training to ensure employees understand and adhere to applicable operating and maintenance procedures.  In the event of a change in the chlorination dechlorination processes, all employees at the facility will be trained within one week. A record of all training will be maintained and shall include:

         A.  Name of the employee,
         B.  Date of the training, and means used to verify that the training was understood               by the employee.

Refresher Training for this facility is scheduled annually during the first quarter of each year. HAZARD ANALYSIS REPORT

1.0		INTRODUCTION

This hazard analysis is for the chlorination and dechlorination processes at the City of Westminster Wastewater Treatment Plant.  The primary purpose of these processes is the disinfection of wastewater plant effluent, control of filamentous bacteria within the plant process and removal of residual chlorine from the plant effluent at the Westminster Wastewater Plant.

2.0		SITE AND FACILITY

This hazard analysis was performed for the chlorination, dechlorination, and return chlorine systems at the following address:

City of Westminster
Wastewater Treatment Plant
1161 Old New Windsor Pike
Westminster, Maryland   21158

3.0		PERSONNEL PERFORMING ANALYSIS

The following persons performed the hazard analysis for this facility:

John Rawlings - Plant Superintendent
Vance Summerhill - Plant Assistant Superintendent
Mark Mellendick - Senior Operator
                        Richard Yoder- Chemist
                        Lynn Blacksten- Third Shift Supervisor
                       James Fritz -Second Shift Supervisor
                       Jeff Glass -Assistant Director of Streets and Utilities
4.0		METHODOLOGY

A ?What-If? Checklist was used to perform the hazard analysis.

5.0		SYSTEM DESCRIPTION AND EQUIPMENT ANALYZED

One ton chlorine and/or sulfur containers are delivered on a flatbed trailer and unloaded with a two (2) ton electric chain hoist on a monorail system.  The normal deliveries are two (2) one ton containers of chlorine and/or sulfur dioxide.  The possibility exists for both chlorine and sulfur dioxide to be delivered in the same delivery, two (2) cylinders each.  The normal delivery for 150 pound cylinders are in a covered truck at quantities up to ten (10) cylinders at a time.  It should be noted that an empty one ton container weights 1550 pounds.  Full 2,000 pound containers a

re normally stored in a pit designed to hold (2) two cylinders. Smaller 150 pound cylinders are stored in the upright position and fastened to the wall with a chain.




Two (2) one ton containers are attached to the chlorination system at all times and two (2) one ton sulfur dioxide cylinders are attached to the dechlorination system at all times.  These containers are positioned in the center of the room on trunnions with individual loadcells for weight measurement.  The load cells for the chlorination system are wired to a Wizard 4000 cylinder scales unit manufactured by Force Flow Equipment in Concord, California.  The load cells for the dechlorination system are hydraulic with analog readouts manufactured by Force Flow Equipment.  These instruments are for monitoring the daily usage of chlorine and sulfur dioxide.  Cylinder tare weights supplied by the chemical manufacturer are used to calculate the remaining quantities of chemical in the cylinder.

Two (2) 150 pound chlorine cylinders are attached to the return chlorination system at all times.  These containers are positioned in the upright position on a Wallace and Tiernan 150 pound cylinder scale system.  Full cylinders are positioned on the scale and the scale is adjusted to read 150 pounds.  When the cylinder is empty the scales read zero.

The chlorination and dechlorination systems at the Westminster Wastewater Treatment Plant are equipped with all of the necessary apparatuses, including but not limited to approved valves, whips, piping, flanges, vacuum regulators, filters, gauges, sensors, annunciator alarms, etc., for feeding this extremely hazardous chemical.  Further, the piping and valving configurations have been so installed as to provide maximum flexibility and feed options.

The ton chlorine and sulfur dioxide containers are filled to a 70/30 - chlorine liquid to gas ratio.  Chlorine and or sulfur dioxide can be drawn off of these containers as either a liquid or a gas.  This can be

accomplished by the proper positioning of the two valves on the face of the chlorine or sulfur dioxide containers.  When these containers are set on the trunnions and prepared for service, the container is rotated so the valves are in a vertical perspective.  The top valve draws off gas that can be directly fed through a chlorinator or dechlorinator whichever the case may be.  The wastewater plant is not equipped to feed liquid chlorine or liquid sulfur dioxide.

The safe yield of chlorine or sulfur dioxide gas off of a one ton container is 400 pounds per day and 40 pounds per day from a 150 pound cylinder.  If the demands are greater than this, the gas will quickly turn into a solid and render the chlorination and or the dechlorination system inoperative.  The only mode of operation at the Westminster facility is to feed regulated chlorine and sulfur dioxide gas directly to the chlorinators and dechlorinators, where the demands are significantly lower than the 400 pounds per day maximum withdraw rate.

Chlorinators and dechlorinators at the Westminster plant are the solution-feed vacuum type.  A water injector is used to create a vacuum that draws the chlorine and sulfur dioxide gas through the chlorinator and/or dechlorinator and provide a solution feed.  The chlorine and sulfur dioxide gas is maintained under vacuum throughout the chlorinators and dechlorinators.

This type of chlorine and sulfur dioxide feed equipment is highly recommended because safe operation is assured.  The chlorine or sulfur dioxide gas feed is automatically shut off if the water pressure used to draw the vacuum is stopped for any reason.

The average daily usage of chlorine at the Westminster Plant is 125 pounds per day and for sulfur dioxide the average rate is 150 pounds per day at the present average daily flows.  The chlorine and sulfur dioxide demand will vary with the average daily flow and clarity of the final effluent.  Currently, at the influent of the contact tank the ch

lorine residual is 1.6 mg/l.  After two hours detention of time the residual is 0.9 mg/1 and not greater that 0.1 mg/1 at discharge to the receiving waters.

See photographs of chlorination systems and devices in Section IV.

There are, however, several opportunities for risk reduction.  Detailed results of the ?What-If? analysis are included in Attachment A.  Risk reduction measures and implementation schedules for the hazards identified  are summarized in the detailed hazard analysis sheets of Attachment B.

The points of a potential chlorine or sulfur dioxide release are virtually any piece of equipment containing chlorine and/or sulfur dioxide.  The most obvious points of release are piping joints, valves, and the special fusible plugs used on ton containers to relieve pressure in the event of overheating.  Other potential release points include the walls and seams of piping or vessels if these were damaged.  Such damage could occur from corrosion or over stress from physical impact or other abuse.  For any part of the chlorination system the primary potential causes of releases are: operating errors; equipment damage from physical or undetected corrosion; and fire.

The majority of chlorine release s

cenarios (discussed in the following subsections) would result in leaks that would be less that catastrophic, and less than the 2,500 pounds of chlorine within a one (1) hour period.  Because chlorine is stored in and used directly from one ton containers, it would require the complete discharge of a single one ton container simultaneously with, a partial discharge of one (1) or more additional containers to achieve such a large release quantity.  Such as release quantity could also occur with the partial discharge of at least two (2) or more ton containers such that the total of all the discharges equaled or exceeded 2,500 pounds.

6.1	Fire Hazards 		

Minimal fire hazards exist that would impact upon the chlorination system and components.  In the event of a fire, adequate fire protection exists nearby in the form of fire extinguishers.




6.2		Impact Hazards

If fire can be eliminated as a potential cause for an accidental release at this facility, an accidental release due to line breakage or container rupture from physical impact may be the next most credible catastrophic accident.  The most likely scenario would be if someone were to trip and fall onto the flexible connections which connect the supply containers to the tank switch over, since this connection represents the weakest component in the piping system.  However, since only one cylinder is being drawn off at a time the maximum possible release from a broken chlorine line would be 2,000 lbs. of gas chlorine or sulfur dioxide at a flow rate of about 16 lb/min at 70 F.  For a full container, at this rate, it would take approximately 125 minutes or just over two hours for the entire contents of the container to be released.

6.3		Fusible Plug Failure

The corrosion induced failure (total loss) of a fusible plug may also be a credible event leading to catastrophic release.  Corrosion induced failures of fusible plugs have occurred in the past on these containers, according to a spokesman fo

r the Chlorine Institute.  However, a simultaneous failure of at least two (2) pounds in one (1) hours.  The failure frequency of such a release was calculated as the failure frequency of one (1) of the components multiplied by the probability that the other component would fail at the same time.  Because failure frequency data is not currently available for fusible plugs, failure data for similar equipment components compiled for the general nuclear and chemical industries was used.  Such data for a number of components is presented in Table 3.  Assuming that a fusible plug can be simulated as a pipe or welded pipe joint, the failure frequency of simultaneous corrosion induced failure on two (2) separate ton containers was estimated to be nearly zero.  Details of this calculation are presented in Attachment C.  Therefore, in the absence of fire, the simultaneous failure of fusible plugs on two (2) containers does not appear to be a credible accident.

6.4		Operator Error

Operator error is one of the more common causes of accidents in the chemical process industries.  The ?failure frequency? for several types of operator error are presented in Table 3.  The most probable operator error which would lead to a chlorine or sulfur dioxide release is likely to occur during replacement of the supply containers on the chlorine or sulfur dioxide scales.  Movement of the ton containers with the electric hoist and lifting beam presents the greatest potential for impact damage due to operator error.  Small releases of chlorine may also result if the operator follows the incorrect procedures when replacing the flexible connection, or forgets to replace the lead washer every time a new container is connected.  However, such omissions are unlikely to lead to large releases of chlorine, especially not exceeding 2,500 pounds in one (1) hour, since this would have to involve simultaneous releases from two (2) containers.



6.5		Terrorist Activity	


     Since September

11, 2001 there has been a heightened national awareness of the possibility of terrorist activity. Although unlikely due to size and location of the wastewater plant the threat of terrorist activity could result in a catastrophic release in a number of ways including the theft of a one ton container. To prevent this all gates and doors protecting the containers remain locked 24 hours a day 7 days a week.

This section present the "What - If" analysis prepared for the chlorination dechlorination facility at the Westminster Wastewater Treatment Plant.

The following questions were answered in this analysis:

What if . . .

Electrical power fails?

Chlorine gas line breaks?

Chlorine container ruptures?

Fire engulfs chlorine container(s)?

Chlorine container is dropped from hoise?

Chlorine truck overturns on property while delivering containers?

Chlorine detector fails to detect leak?

Operator fails to close container valve before disconnecting the tank                               mount regulator?

Ton cylinder internal induction pipe is broke off and liquid chlorine or sulfur                                 dioxide is drawn into the gas system?

Water flow through injector stops? 

Chlorine vacuum regulator fails to shut off when vacuum  fails?

RESULTS

What if electrical power fails?

The chances of a chlorine release from electrical power failure are minimal due emergency backup power units.  In the event of an electrical power failure, the generator will generate power for the entire plant.  Generators are tested under load every week

The facility has little control over receiving and overfilled container.  Since ton containers are normally on scales as they are being refilled by the supplier, and the final shipping weight of each container is normally recorded, the chances of receiving an overfilled container from the supplier are minimal.

Excessive physical shock could occur by collision between a container and another object while the container is on the delivery truck, during transfer from the truck or within the facility.  Specified proper handling procedures and equipment are used to prevent this from occurring.  According to a spokesman from the Chlorine Institute, the containers themselves are designed to withstand considerable physical shock and are reported to be capable of withstanding a drop of over ten (10) feet onto a hard surface.

Excessive heat or fire is a possible cause of container rupture under certain circumstances, e.g., if the container was exposed to a high temperature heat source and the fusible plugs failed to melt, or if the container was overfilled by the supplier, subjected to a temperature increase after arriving at the facility, and became liquid full.  As discussed in the Hazard Analysis, the chances that a fire will occur at our near the chlorine facility are minimal.
The chlorine storage room is heated with forced air heaters. For this heat source (assuming the room was overheated because of a faulty thermostat or incorrect setting).  pressures sufficient to a rupture a container without defects would only occur if the container were overfilled with liquid chlorine or sulfur dioxide to begin with.

What if fire engulfs the chlorine containers?

See the above discussion.  Based on the design of the buildings where chlorine and sulfur dioxide are stored, there does not seem to be a plausible mechanism fire or fire exposure to the chlorine and/or sulfur containers at this facility.

What if a chlorine container is dropped from a hoist?

See previous

discussion concerning chlorine container ruptures.  If a chlorine or sulfur dioxide container was moved or lifted without the safety cover being properly bolted in place over the container valves, the valves could be damaged or sheared off.  Written operating procedures for this facility require that the covers be properly secured whenever the containers are moved.  Ton containers should be moved at minimum height above ground or obstruction.  smaller 150 pound cylinders are secured in the upright position by a chair or are strapped to the scales with a chain when in service.  Before any cylinders are moved the valve cover is screwed in place.

What if a chlorine truck overturns on the property while delivering containers?

See previous discussion on chlorine container ruptures and chlorine container dropped from hoist.  The containers themselves are designed to withstand considerable physical impact and are protected by a safety cover.  Delivery trucks should move with caution at low speeds through a very open access area with little hazard of collision or overturn.  In the event of this or any emergency involving chlorine, Emergency Response will immediately be summoned by dialing 911.



What if the chlorine or sulfur dioxide detector fails to detect leak?

The leak would eventually be detected by odor of chlorine or sulfur dioxide leaking from the chlorine building or storage area.  Appropriate response measures would then be taken.  It is possible that the failure of a detector to detect a leak could result in a larger release than would have otherwise occurred.  However, the detectors will be checked monthly for operational readiness and serviced under the preventive maintenance program according to the facility's written operating procedures or manufacturer's specifications.




What if the operator/maintenance person fails to close the container valve before disconnecting the vacuum regulator?

The operator/maintenance person unhooking the r

egulator would already be wearing an S.C.B.A., immediately determine the mistake and close the valve with the same wrench that he/she was removing the regulator with.  Safe operating procedures for changing a cylinder provide step-by-step instructions.  A second operator is monitoring the cylinder changing through a window from outside the building ready, to assist if needed with a second S.C.B.A. unit.

What if the internal induction pipe on a ton cylinder is broke off and liquid chlorine or sulfur dioxide is drawn into the gas system?

The chlorination and dechlorination systems are piped with PVC pipe and fittings, liquid chlorine and sulfur will attack the PVC causing a potential hazard.  If this happens, the defective tank would be disconnected and rotated so that the second valve can be utilized providing that the second valve is intact.  If both valves are defective the cylinder would be sent back to the supplier.  The system would be inspected for damaged components and repairs would be made before returning it to service.

What if the water flow through the injectors stop?

Once water flow through injectors stops, the vacuum is lost and chlorine and/or sulfur dioxide ceases t feed.  This becomes a static condition posing no apparent danger from chlorine or sulfur dioxide.

WESTMINSTER
Wastewater Treatment Plant
Background Information

The Westminster Wastewater Tr

eatment Plant is owned and operated by the City of Westminster, serving approximately 32,500 citizens.  Twelve sewer pumping stations and some 65 miles of sewer lines convey raw wastewater from the end user to the wastewater plant located at the corner of Route 31 and Old New Windsor Pike.  The City's wastewater plant is an activated sludge process designed to treat five million gallon of wastewater per/day.

Raw wastewater enters the plant through a 48 inch influent line. Trash is removed by means of an automated bar screen.  Grease and grit are removed via a Schreiber Grease and Grit removal system.  After primary treatment, the screened flow, travels through open channels to a splitter mechanism. Raw wastewater and plant return activated sludge are combined at the influent slitter mechanism and divided between four reactors. This plant is an M.L.E. biological nutrient removal system. After biological treatment, tertiary treatment is achieved by adding aluminum sulfate (Alum)to the mixed liquor for reduction of phosphorous levels in the effluent.  The mixed liquor is divided between three secondary clarifiers to separate the clear treated water from the return activated sludge.  The return sludge pumping station is the location of the return chlorine system.  As described earlier in the plan return chlorine is for the control of filamentous bacteria in the biological process.  After clarification, the flow (plant effluent) is chlorinated in the chlorine contact tank.  Effluent flow through a raceway of baffles to ensure the chlorine solution is thoroughly mixed with the effluent.  Flow measurement is taken prior to flow entering the dechlorination chamber by an ultrasonic flow meter.  In the dechlorination chamber a sulfonated water solution is added to neutralize the residual chlorine remaining in the effluent.  Air is induced in the dechlorination chamber to provide mixing and elevate the effluent dissolved oxygen to meet N.P.D.E.S. permit requirements.  The t

reated final effluent flows to the Chesapeake Bay tributary Little Pipe Creek.

VIII.	PRE-STARTUP REVIEWS

A pre-startup safety review will be conducted prior to startup of a new process or a modified process that is no longer significantly

covered by the existing process safety information. The pre-startup safety review shall confirm the following.
        
   1. Construction and equipment is in accordance with design specifications.
   2.  Safety, operating, maintenance, and emergency procedures are in place and are           adequate.
   3. A process hazard analysis has been performed and recommendations have been          resolved or implemented.
   4. Training of all employees of the wastewater treatment plant has been completed.

      The pre-startup safety review team will be composed of the city engineer, the utilities manager, and the management staff of the Westminster  Wastewater Treatment Plant.
   
     In addition to assuring that the construction and equipment used in the new or modified chemical process is in accordance with design specifications the pre-startup review will also consider other factors. The construction equipment must also be ?replacement in kind?. If the construction and equipment is not ?replacement in kind? then the pre-startup review must also include management of change procedures. 

     Management of change procedures ensure that current programs are applicable to the new process and if they are not changes are made to ensure that the programs are in compliance. Programs that may require updating include process and instrumentation diagrams, operating procedures, safety training, maintenance, and emergency procedures. If the changes are significant and the programs require updating then all employees of the wastewater treatment plant will receive refresher training prior to startup. Any new training requirements will then become permanent of the annual training program.

INCIDENT INVESTIGATION

    The primary purpose of the Westminster Wastewater Treatment Plants Process Safety Management Plan is to prevent the catastrophic release of chlorine and/ or sulfur dioxide to the environment. With this goal in mind an investigative team composed of the city engineer, the utilities manager and the management staff of the wastewater treatment plant was formed. The responsibilities of the investigative team include developing a program to prevent any catastrophic release from occurring and to investigate all incidents or accidents which resulted in, or could reasonably have resulted in a catastrophic release. All investigations will be initiated within 48 hours of the occurrence. In the event that a contractor, subcontractor or associated employees are involved in an incident a representative of the contractor, subcontractor or associated employee will be included in the investigative team. 

    The following procedures will be used for conducting an investigation.

    1. Within 48 hours those individuals involved in the incident will be interviewed and the area in which the incident occurred will be investigated.	

    2. Based on the results of the interview process and the investigative process a cause of the incident will be determined.

    3. Recommendations for preventive and / or corrective measures to prevent similar incidents from occurring in the future.
 
    4. A written report will be filed with the city engineer documenting any findings. The report shall include :
                                   
       A. Date and time of the incident
       B. Date of investigation
       C. Description of incident
       D. Factors contributing to the incident

   At the

conclusion of the incident investigation any recommendations will be promptly addressed and preventive/ corrective measures will be implemented by the management staff of the Westminster Wastewater Treatment Plant. All preventative / corrective measures will be documented and maintained as part of the Audit and Training Compliance Schedule. Findings of the investigative team will be reviewed with all plant operating personnel and retraining, if necessary, will be conducted.
